newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Low advances hit ABB oper profit.
newsitem.headline: Low advances hit ABB oper profit.

text.p: ABB Asea Brown Boveri AG's nine month operating earnings rose less than its net income due to a decline in the imputed interest income on customer advance payments, a company spokesman said.
"If interest on advances are excluded from both periods, operating earnings rose 17 percent," an ABB spokesman said in response to inquiries.
ABB books interest income on customer advances under revenue. However, it then subtracts the amount to avoid double counting.
ABB's interest on advances fell to $554 million from $702 million last year.
This decline had a negative effect on ABB's operating earnings, but no impact on pre-tax or net profit, ABB said.
ABB's nine month operating earnings rose four percent to $2.1 billion, while net profit rose 24 percent to $809 million.
The rise in operating earnings was based on productivity gains, the establishment of low-cost manufacturing bases, and previous restructuring, ABB said in its nine month report.
The operating margin in the first nine months was steady at 8.7 percent.

"The improvement in operating earnings was achieved despite a competitive environment for new power equipment, higher material costs, and lower contribution from its transportation activities," ABB said.
